column4: ah! I deleted my partition table on a harddrive, is it possible to recover the data it was pointing to?
ah! I deleted my partition table on a harddrive, is it possible to recover the data it was pointing to?
ah! I deleted my partition table on a harddrive, is it possible to recover the data it was pointing to?
The data isn't gone; if you recreate the partition table (just create partitions again with the same starting/ending cylinder numbers) you should be able to access it just fine
ah that's what I thought. What is this process called so I can google it
so do I just do fdisk from the beginning of the partition to the end with the same filesystem as before?
use fdisk to create partitions with the same starting and ending cylinders and the same type codes
(actually, the type code is only a hint to the OS, and doesn't actually have anything to do with the contents of the partition)
the byte in the partition table that indicates what the partition is for, e.g. 0x83 for Linux
ah I think I know what you mean. 82 for Linux :D
thanks for that I'll play around on a test drive
but it has nothing to do with the partition's contents; you could make a partition labeled 0x82 and put NTFS in it
Windows probably wouldn't "notice" it, but you could still mount it with ntfs-3g or whatever
oh ok, and would that be able to boot?
oh I see... probably lazy windows coding

I don't know what Windows' policy is on detecting filesystems in partitions...  the point is that the type code in the partition table is just a hint to the OS that it *can* use to decide which partitions to look at and which to ignore
